title: I don't think that anyone below Diamond
body:
Should be able to use their own games/gameplay as a reference when discussing the balance of a champion.

I think they should be able to comment on the balance, I just don't think they should be able to use their gameplay as an example of balance.

The reason I feel this way, is that if a Bronze V player was to say that Yasuo was imbalanced (before all his nerfs), that player would be correct, but if that player said Yasuo was imbalanced because his team got stomped by Yasuo, I feel like there are some core components of understanding and gameplay that are lacking in Bronze V that could have allowed his/her team to beat the Yasuo that would invalidate the argument of his being OP.

I was in Bronze V for well over a year before getting the Gold V I am today, and I know first hand that there are simply things people in Bronze don't know of or think about in terms of balance. The most common one that I'm seeing lately is that Gnar is OP because:

- he is resourceless
- he has a low CD Q that applies a slow
and
- he has an escape

While these are somewhat valid points, some things that Bronze players may not think about (I surely didn't when I was in Bronze V) are that his Q CD is HELLA long if he doesn't catch his boomerang, his Q is EXTREMELY unlikely to hit you if he hits a minion with it first (remember the tutorial? "Stay behind your minions"). Lastly, of course, his hop is on a relatively long CD.

How many people in Bronze actually punish a Gnar if he uses his Hop? I know for a fact I wouldn't have done that when I was in Bronze.

By the same token, saying that a champion IS balanced because you stomped one pretty hard in your game has next to no meaning when you're in Bronze. Using the Gnar example again, certain game knowledge, such as positioning, is required to play Gnar well. If you're opponent doesn't have that ability, then it is only natural that they would get stomped, regardless of what champion they are on.

So, based on that, I don't think that lower level players should be barred from discussing matters of balance, I just don't think that their own gameplay is valid as an example in discussions of balance.

Thoughts?

replies.body:
I think it absolutely makes no sense. Asserting that someone has a diamond as an authority in their argument is fine, but stating that its all that matters is a logical fallacy. 

1. Rank is no guarantee of skill, but it may contain an expectation value if you treated rank statistically
2. Rank is no guarantee of observational ability, for instance, someone may not be good at the game but see something hidden among their bad game play as being irrefutably broken.
3. Rank is no guarantee of intelligence, which is just a generalization of 2 and 1.

Please re-read what I said. I said that all ranks should be allowed to discuss balance, however, anyone below diamond should not be posting their own gameplay as a factor in balance (i.e. a Silver player saying that Thresh is OP because he got beat in top lane by a Thresh.)

> Please re-read what I said. I said that all ranks should be allowed to discuss balance, however, anyone below diamond should not be posting their own gameplay as a factor in balance (i.e. a Silver player saying that Thresh is OP because he got beat in top lane by a Thresh.)

Then I invite you to reread statement 2. Particularly the part where the person still uses his game play because he knows its irrefutably broken.

Completely agree with you. Best example of this would be the pubstompers like Darius. It's a fact that for some champions, the win rate goes down as the elo goes up. While it is possible for players of lower rank to discover imbalances of the game, a majority of their complaints would be able to be explained by "champion counter", or more commonly, outplays. If a {{champion:238}}  #rekts a {{champion:10}}  in lane, does it mean that Zed is super IMBA? not really...it's because jg pressure, or skill difference.

I'd like to take a moment, just sit right there... (sorry, had to... :( )

But seriously, I'd like to take a moment to thank you for PROPERLY reading what I typed. You're probably 1 of 2 people that has. :(

The community is full of people who victimize themselves for anything that is not "ty" and "please". Sometimes I honestly feel like this is a game for pre-teens...because the words "don't matter" and "bellow diamond" both appeared in ur thread it is automatically degrading to lower elo players.

So if you aren't Diamond you are Bronze scrub who is clueless?  There is a vast spectrum of skill levels in this game.  I mean the same argument could be used against Diamond in favor of Challenger and pro players.  In the end this game needs to be relatively balanced for all skill levels.  It's not healthy for the game if a really easy champ is super powerful while only being counterable by high elo players, because that champ is still ruining the game for the low elo players.  All levels of play have to be considered when balancing unfortunately.  This is why you will never see perfect balance across all levels of play.  The pub stompers get nerfed because they are too strong against low elo players and that results in them being a tad bit weak in elite level play oftentimes.  All champs being balanced at all levels of play is simply not possible, so they have to address the level of play where champs are overpowered first and foremost.

The only issue that I have with what you say, is that people that have a baser understanding of positioning (i.e. staying behind minions against skill-shots that are stopped by minions), will make a champion balanced, whereas people (generally Bronze V) who DON'T have this concept, will make said champion look ridiculously OP.

By no means am I saying that you're either diamond or a "bronze scrub", in fact, I never said "Bronze Scrub" once in my original post, so thanks for putting words in my mouth.

As for the rest, you'll notice that I'm Gold V, which means that I don't believe I should be able to use even MY OWN gameplay/games as examples in these types of discussions.

So again, I'd like to thank you for putting words in my mouth, and kindly invite you to re-read what I posted, maybe a little slower this time so you can comprehend what I actually posted and, maybe, not put words in my mouth again.
I didn't put words in your mouth.  I interpreted what you were saying by you referring to a bronze players as your sole example to prove your original point.

You're right, my apologies for saying Bronze (being that it is the furthest example for people that don't understand the game), when I meant to say "Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Plat".

Nevermind the fact that I've said that my own gameplay is irrelevant in balance discussions... I'm Gold V.

I've said this to people before and I'll say it again.  If Riot balances this game for Diamond and above only it will become very imbalanced for the rest of us.  And the rest of us comprises 90% of the players of this game.

Excellent!

I would accept this argument, I really would, accept for one thing...

RIOT IS ALREADY CATERING SPECIFICALLY TO THE PRO SCENE WITH MOST OF THE CHANGES THEY'RE MAKING TO THE GAME.

The game is ALREADY being catered to the pro scene because Riot got a taste of the "good stuff" when the professional scene appeared, and with how quickly it's taken off. The professional scene is where they make their money.

Now, if this was a video game which was free to play, and had no professional scene, I would completely agree that you should balance to the majority, that's absolutely 100% without a doubt the way to go, yes.

HOWEVER, the second that the Pro Scene took over as a main source of income for Riot, that kind of had to change.

You think most of their changes are geared for pro play?  They constantly nerf pub stompers that don't see much play in the LCS.  They also make changes aimed at solo queue rather than organized team play.  Riot has no interest in trying to make all their champs pro viable by the way, quite the opposite actually.

Let's see, what changes have they made recently that I would be talking about?

* Changing the jungle
* Changing Dragon reward
* Changing turrets
* Changing Cannon Minion spawn rates

I think I missed some... however.

The jungle changes, the Dragon changes, even the changes to turrets, are changes based around making the game more of a team game. This results in more of a need for communication, WHICH SOLO QUEUE DOESN'T HAVE.

I'd say that these changes are probably the biggest, and they're most definitely not aimed at Bronze level solo queue.

> I've said this to people before and I'll say it again.  If Riot balances this game for Diamond and above only it will become very imbalanced for the rest of us.  And the rest of us comprises 90% of the players of this game.

And if they "balance" for the rest of us, it will not actually be balanced at all. It will make no sense. The very concept of balance implies maximally using your champion and not "but then I ulted a minion."

I don't think that just because some1 is tagged Diamond should have the right to judge other ppl that probably just don't bother to lose their lives around a game that they can play at high levels without needing a tag to boost their ego.

Edit: Constructive criticism

While ofc Dia players have accomplished something that many players couldn't. The knowledge of certain champions/mechanics/balance opinions shouldn't be judged upon a game tag that doesn't offer a view of single player skills but rather how the whole team acted (and bad players here have a far bigger impact on the result rather then good players).

Now, what should a person be judged for is their feedback and knowledge of what they are talking about. I can know inside-out a champion and compare it to others I know/have played against better than Dia 1 players that probably never met said champions.

Also there is that different ppl can have different approach to the same champions without making one worse than the other. Using Leagues as an argument against a player is pure bullshize and unless you are talking about the team enviroment (Gold/Silver players don't have experience of how teams work in Dia, that's ok) you have no right to think you are better at judging X champion and anyway the vision of the other person might take in aspects of the matter you didn't consider.

Um.. ok?

Not once did I say anything relating to what you just said... Thanks.

Discussions of balance aren't people in Diamond looking down on everyone else, they're discussions of balance.

However, if a Silver, Bronze, or Gold player (even platinum to some extent), gives an example of something that happened in their game as a reason for a champion being OP or UP or otherwise imbalanced, then I don't believe that "evidence" is valid in the discussion based on reasons that I've mentioned MANY many times in this thread.

You replied probably befopre I edited xD I hope you'd take time to read that part too. I do agree to some extent but blatantly ignoring something because happened in a lower League I don't think it's right too. If something is related to how the team enviroment is you should add that to the discussion ofc and if the other ppl ignores your feedback then there is no doubt that he is the one at fault.

The reason I said what I did though, is because people that lack the ability or game knowledge that is found in Diamond tend to, just... run into the enemy without thinking?

A GREAT example of this would be Darius, if you just run at him and die 2 times, you CAN'T get near him again or he'll keep killing you because that's just how his kit is.

Now, with that in mind, a Diamond player will know to kite Darius, and will be able to beat him in lane after playing against him a few times. A Bronze or silver player (even gold to some extent, Darius is stronger the lower you go though) however, will see Darius, think to themselves, "well F***", and proceed to not try kiting, or fail at kiting due to poor mechanics, and feed away. I know, because I was that feeder in MANY games when I was Bronze and Silver. I STILL have that issue with some champions, but I'm trying to work on it every game that I play.

As it turns out, Darius was overpowered upon release. However, it wasn't because you couldn't beat him in lane (as many a Bronze and Silver claimed), it was because of his ult, and how HORRIBLY good it was in teamfights mid to late game.

This is a great example because it shows that Bronze and Silver players CAN be right when discussing balance, they said he was OP, he was OP. However, using their gameplay as an example would suggest that Darius had issues outside of his ult if they, like me, fed him over and over again in lane.

So I say that everyone's opinion matters yes, but not everyone's gameplay does, because if you're just walking up to ANY CHAMPION and letting them kill you, of course they're going to stomp the game. This is, of course, the heaviest example of what I'm talking about.

Yes but I would like to point out that a Bronze player would still be able to identify that his ult is OP (back then) even if part of the reason was that they fed him earlier.

For example lets say that you feed Darius a couple of early kills. Then he ults you and kills you. His ult resets and this is before the 20 second timer. That means that he has it up every time until he uses it and doesn't get a kill.

This is true regardless of whether or not the Darius is fed though. Because let's say that there's a Darius and a Fiora. Both equal. They teamfight. They both ult and Darius gets his ult reset. The next teamfight Darius will have his ult while Fiora wont since her's has a long CD.

While a Bronze player might not focus on on the actual problem with the champion as on the problem with the game they just played they will be able to identify it. 

I would also like to mention that this game is for everyone regardless of their rank. So despite a Bronze players perceived lack of game knowledge and poor mechanics if a lot of them are having problems with a certain champion for whatever reason then that needs to be looked at even if the people complaining did mess up horribly.

The Darius example was merely an example, I'm sure if you read all of my replies in this thread, you'll find something that will satisfy your discomfort on the matter.

I'd suggest the reply where I mention Monte Cristo. Though that one may be a tad abrasive, I haven't slept yet, and the lack of reading comprehension is killing me.

I have read your posts and I do understand them.

I realize that I'm probably saying something unnecessary or repeating myself and others but I wanted to get my opinion out there.

While you may have a point in feeling that lower elo players correlate broken champions with extremely polar performances which are rather inconsistent, I woulnd't say lower elo play cannot in anyway determine the balance of champions. If there is a trend for a champion to be "stomping" in lower elo there may be more to it than just a lack of knowledge of skill of the majority of the playerbase. What better way can you evaluate the power of champions if you cannot reflect on your own play, to tell people to think of their opinions as lesser greatly diminishes room for growth and understanding for the game. You may notice this post of mine and try to defend yourself, perhaps by saying you didnt mean to "x".

 But I'd rather you not do that because what this basically comes down to is the mindset of the individual. Many people will read your topic, many wont, I hope the ones that do do not feel their experiences are false or  are of lesser value merely because they lack a wealth of experience. Players of any elo will hold ignorant opinions of champions and bits and pieces of the actual truth when it comes to the actual balance of a said champion, it's just tha tin higher elo theres more likely a chance that reasonable counter play is developed because they've already been through those growing pains.

 I read these forums a lot and not every Diamond player agrees with their fellow diamond peers and that doesnt make them any more or less valid. If there's counter play or a reasonable argument to be made then allow everyone to present their case, don't encourage exclusion of opinion and unnecessary elitism because balance will never be a lightly debated issue. Thus every opinion matters.

>Thus every opinion matters.

I'm... I'm fairly certain I have said EXACTLY THIS in many of my replies on this thread. So while you say that I'll defend myself by saying "I didn't mean 'x'", you're right, because you didn't understand what I was saying.

I was saying that EVERY OPINION MATTERS, but the gameplay of said opinions do not necessarily matter when it comes to balance. Now, whether this be due to mechanical issues, or people not understanding things about the game, doesn't really matter.

People in lower elos do not perform on champions well enough for the gameplay to be an indication of balance. Anyone, however, can watch a lot of the LCS and be able to see, at least to some extent (or even just look over the stats etc.) and be able to wage an opinion on the balance of a champion.

As an example, I'm Gold V. I don't see my gameplay as being important in the discussion of balance, simply because I know that I have flaws that would skew said balance (as do many MANY MANY people in Gold.) However, I still assert that Poppy will (and I told this to a friend of mine prior to the 4.20 patch) become more dominant with Patch 4.20. We saw some dominance from her in the IEM tournament where UoL used her against C9.

However, this particular example has nothing to do with why I feel she will become dominant. Why? Because I theorize that she'll become more dominant because of the changes to the regen stat. With the regen stat being the most effective way to make Poppy tanky with her passive, I feel like the changes to HP regen will bring her to the point where Morello will completely annihilate her (and UoL built no regen on Poppy in that game).

Just my thoughts on your post.

To quickly touch on my comment in regards to you defending yourself, I didn't want to engage in that because it would be a moot side conversation that would delve into personal opinion of manners, decency, self respect and so forth. Our opinions on such things probably greatly differ and thus wouldn't edify the conversation and only cause friction I just wanted to express what I gathered from your post, knowing it would end up in agreeing to disagree. With that being said I understand your logic behind lower elo game play and like you I watch alot of pro play as well as read alot of guides and such. I don't know many things and I learn a lot with every viewing, read and new champion I pick up. While I do not see my individual success in solo queue as concrete evidence of character balance, I do not make the mistake of discrediting my impact, my peers impact and my overall experience in my current elo as it regards the strength of champions. Doing so results in two things.

-**You start to think that Champions are totally fine and blame others (or yourself) for failure or success.
-You do not seek a greater understanding of the meta, why it is, and it's possible future changes because what you pcik doesnt matter at your elo**.

You cannot watch pros and think you know how to play because you watch pros, you need to devlop yourself in practice and discrediting the majority if not all of your personal observation sets you back a lot. Yes you will quite often stumble upon something you feel is imbalance but will either not understand fully the reasons for the outcome or completely miss it altogether. But failure to understand and learning from that misunderstanding is better than keeping yourself in ignorance and stumping your own intellect. No matter what elo you are one thing remains constant in League and that is the expanding/renewing of your mind. 

To be better at league you must learn and understand things. You must research things  and stumble upon crucial things the average or casual player does not find in their everyday play so early. You need to discover the game for yourself, their is no guide to success. I don't think the message you want to get across is wrong, it's just poorly worded. In short I agree lower elo players shouldnt use their performances as the primary basis for "truth" in the game. Much of thier experiences will be unrefined, however they need to compare and contrast in order to gain a discernment and understanding. Thus by engaging with thier own experiences while keeping in mind the circumstances of those experiences value can be taken, even in the most suboptimal of scenarios.

To some extent, you're absolutely right. You can't just be told "you have to be better at CS'ing so that you have a better chance of climbing" and immediately get better at the game.

At first glance, getting better at CS would indicate that you have to increase your CS/minute, or how much CS you have at x minutes in the game or whatever. Which seems right, at first glance.

However, getting better at CS is not only getting higher CS, but also knowing which CS to NOT go for. In other words, if you're a melee, and you're against Akali in lane pre-6, and she hits you with her Q and drops her shroud on the minions, you better believe that taking those two CS will result in you getting chunked for a GOOD amount of your health: probably best to let them slide for the time being.

Now, even though I just explained a very SPECIFIC instance of what "being good at cs" means. This doesn't apply the same way to every champion, or every matchup. It is, in fact, VERY specific to certain Akali matchups. However, with that knowledge, people should know better what to look for to get better at CS'ing. Now it's up to them as to whether they use that knowledge or not, and start to actually think about how they can get better.
I don't understand the downvotes. Your points are pretty obvious but also 100% valid.

I don't understand them either, but hey... throw out a controversial opinion and people will likely throw feces at you. I'm neither surprised nor hurt.

For anyone saying that I'm obviously hurt because I defend my opinion, you need to learn how to have a backbone. Anyone that throws an opinion and is flamed has one of two options:

* stick to their guns
* back down

In the first instance, people will say "oh you're just butthurt and refuse to back down."

In the second, they're called weak.

Sad, but the world we live in none-the-less.

To be fair, you can't really exclude the lower half of the community from showing match history in any discussion. Just because they aren't in high ELO play does not mean they don't know what they're doing. Sometimes, yes, lower levels of ranked aren't going to be based on the split-second reaction timing high rankings face, and the gameplay is going to be different, but these people make up more than half of the ranked community (there was a post with statistics about ranked I saw before, can't remember it now, but the general gist was that all bronze and silver players outnumber all other rankings (excluding gold)).

Never judge a way someone thinks or plays the game based on what you personally experienced in bronze. Many of us are very interested in champion balance, and if we have to use our match history to prove a point, then I don't see why not. Many bronzes and silvers know quite a bit about the champions they play, and I don't think excluding the validity of an entire half of the community's match history, which they will use to somehow prove a point, is right.

And before anyone says it, yes, I am Bronze III. Deal with it, bronze haters. *sunglasses*

Ok, I'm going to go ahead and say this as nicely as I can.

I was in Bronze V for over a year because I didn't understand how the game worked (at least, I didn't PROPERLY understand.) Once I started focusing on my issues and started learning about various aspects of the game (like counter-building, positioning, proper CS'ing, etc.) I climbed in UNDER 1 MONTH to Silver V.

After taking a short break from gameplay, and learning more about the game, I climbed to Gold V.

The reason that Diamond players can make smurfs, and intentionally tank to Bronze, only to climb back out again and get back into Diamond, is because they have an understanding that the players in Bronze DON'T HAVE, they have an understanding about the game that Silver players DON'T HAVE, etc. etc.

So, to say that a Bronze game isn't a viable example of a champions balance isn't being biased against Bronze players, it is a statement in truth.

Probably the best example of what I'm trying to say, is the famed jungler: Lee Sin. He's extremely viable and borderline OP in higher level play, but in Bronze he's SOOOOOOOOOO under-powered it's not even funny, unless he gets fed, in which case he'll probably single handedly win the game.

How Lee Sin works in low elo, is how EVERY champion works in low elo. If that doesn't register as a problem to you, I don't know what to say.
The salt in the downvotes is real.
Tell me about it.

I think they're just butthurt because they "think" you're saying their views are invalid, because you know, "muh opinions tho".

I'd blame it on the lack of reading comprehension.
Yea, simple reading comprehension would straighten this out... I blame the education system in the states for this... (yes, I too live in the US.)
Well when you have a one-size-fits-stupid education system in place, that tends to happen.

I agree to an extent, as someone mentioned already, it gets tiresome when you hear yet again about how Darius is OP when you know he's nothing more then a noobstomper. 

However there needs to be feedback tied to game play for all champions, all champions perform differently based on different elos. It's important to know how well/poorly a champion does from every aspect, not just from a Diamond+ game play stance. And how does one attain that? Through game play.

I get what you're saying (Least I think), but its difficult to really offer a proper legitimate opinion on something without game play experience. Furthermore, its difficult to take a person's opinion seriously when they don't have the experience or game play.

It would be like my friends who don't play ice hockey trying to tell me what the best equipment to get is based on watching NHL, some things work in professional or higher level of play that simply don't work at lower play, in my case D3 level college hockey, I could explain, but that's not important. 

Point being, I'm not going to listen to them over my own 18 years of experience because I know what I see in professional play does not translate to my own play. Which is about the same for LoL. The job for Riot and for those of us who are interested in balance are to weed through which ones are legitimate and which ones are nothing more then "OMG WTF champ is HAXOR"

I'm a B1 player. I don't pretend to have nearly as much knowledge as someone of a higher ELO except for Silver which is kind of a glorified Bronze with a God Complex.

I can however identify certain problems with champions even if the circumstances leading to those problems appearing were due to poor play.

While I understand your point I don't think that gameplay experiences should be reserved for Diamond+.

As I said to your post somewhere else on this thread, there's a reply in here about Monte Cristo, it should accurately enough quell whatever discomforts you on the subject. :D

Keep one thing in mind though, I say "people below diamond", I'm only Gold V, so I'm not simply objectifying everyone else, I'm including myself in the group for the same reasons I'm including Bronze and Silver.

Not all diamond players have a good judgement on balance.

All levels of play are relevant to balancing this game. *Game.* Which most people play for fun.

Honestly, I would agree with you, except that NEARLY EVERYTHING Riot is doing balance-wise seems to be based largely around the Pro Scene right now. This means that Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Platinum, have no baring on what "balance" is in Riot's eyes.

::IMPORTANT NOTE::

I do NOT agree with what I just typed entirely, I merely POINTED IT OUT as being RIOT'S PERCEIVED approach on balance (or the perception I get of Riot's view on balance.)

::END NOTE::

Personally, I don't think the actual gameplay of lower levels of play (INCLUDING MY OWN, I'M NOT TARGETTING BRONZE "NOOBS"...) has any baring on what is balanced.

I DO, however, believe that PEOPLE IN THE LOWER ELOS, can have VERY VALID opinions on balance, and shouldn't be discouraged from speaking them, SO LONG AS THEY BRING THEIR GAMEPLAY INTO THE DISCUSSION (please note that I'm including myself in this, I don't think it right for me to say Zed is OP simply because I can't deal with him in midlane...).

::SIDE NOTE::

I hate using capitalization for emphasis, but enough people have seemingly misread what I put in the OP, so I figured I'd try something that most people seem to understand... We'll see how that takes.

If lower levels players can't use their own gameplay or judgement to talk about balance, how could they talk about balance?
